Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Conductivity, diffusion, and dispersion of photoexcited Dirac fermions in cadmium arsenide
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
This study aims at investigating key electronic and optical excitation processes in cadmium
arsenide, one of the recently discovered "Dirac semimetals". Its electrons behave as though they are massless and exhibit very high mobilities and velocities, so the material may be considered the bulk analog of graphene. It is very stable, has a 3-D crystal structure, and can be integrated with existing electronics. It is also a starting material from which to realize a magnetic Weyl semimetal in which, unusually, the direction of the electrons' spin would be determined by the direction of their motion. This research includes the synthesis and characterization of cadmium arsenide bulk crystals and thin films, both
undoped and magnetically-doped, using chemical vapor deposition at reduced temperature. The research
measures electrons' diffusion, and uses several time-resolved probes including terahertz spectroscopy and
photoemission. Improved knowledge of growth methods and electronic properties of 3-D Dirac materials,
as provided by this research, is important in realizing the materials' technological promise. Applications
such as fast electronics, fast or broadband optical sensors, or actively mode-locked lasers all rely on
ultrafast and optical properties explored in this research. This work supports graduate and undergraduate
researchers (the latter at a primarily-undergraduate institution), who engage with the growth and
characterization of cadmium arsenide, operate laser experiments, handle cryogens, write computer code,
and analyze complex sets of data. Because of the scientific and industrial relevance of condensed-matter
physics, and the rapid growth of ultrafast technology, the students become prepared for a wide variety of
scientific and technical careers.

Technical Abstract:
The Dirac and Weyl materials host properties including the chiral anomaly, unusual quantum
magneto-resistance, and predicted giant diamagnetism. Their near-lack of a Fermi surface causes
anomalous transport, with the scattering rate, density of states, and diffusivity strongly dependent on
energy; the conductivity rises linearly with frequency. The materials' restrictive phase-space suggests, in
analogy with graphene, that it should be possible to control their optical and transport properties on subpicosecond timescales, for instance by doping with photoexcited carriers. The investigators explore the
nature of these photoexcited carriers: their density and temperature; their effect on diffusivity and
conductivity; and their dispersion. Of particular interest is identifying the conditions under which photocarriers can exhibit the same distinctive Dirac behaviors as their host material. Selection of different pump-photon energies allow excitation of massless initial states or the higher-energy massive ones. Transient-grating spectroscopy measures photocarriers' diffusivity. Terrahertz spectroscopy measures their conductivity, indicative of scattering rate, chemical potential, and massive or massless character. Time-resolved photoemission reveals the transiently-occupied states invisible to traditional photoemission. Another part of this work improves vapor-based synthesis of cadmium arsenide crystals and films, exploring methods and effects of doping with magnetic atoms and contributing toward the effort to make a ferromagnetic Weyl semimetal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Electrons in the recently-discovered Dirac and Weyl semimetals (DWSs) behave as though massless, leading to a variety of unique optical and electronic properties. When a short laser pulse strikes these materials, it abruptly boosts some of their electrons to higher-energy states, briefly modifying the materials? properties. We have investigated the response of several DWSs to very short laser pulses, including cadmium arsenide, ZrSiS, SrMnSb2, and other materials.  We found strikingly similar behaviors among all these materials. A laser pulse abruptly raises the temperature of electrons in the semimetal by several hundred Kelvin. The electrons then cool over the course of a few picoseconds. We found that the materials' reflectivity can serve as a gauge of the electrons' instantaneous temperature. The reason for the materials? similar behaviors is that their electrons? massless-like behavior allows them to cool particularly quickly.

Materials with different electronic properties are distinguished by the presence of an "energy gap" in their electronic states; DWSs lack a gap, but they almost have one, and their electronic properties are very sensitive to the positions of their atoms. We showed that, in SrMnSb2, it may be possible for laser pulses to open or close an electronic gap, literally in a flash--in much less than a nanosecond. The laser pulse can cause the atoms' positions to vibrate in sync with each other, and this vibration might periodically open or close a gap, 4,400 times per nanosecond. This work could allow a laser to act as an ultra-fast switch, quickly and reversibly controlling the semimetal's electronic properties.

We made a light-sensor out of a crystal of cadmium arsenide suspended between two electrodes. The device detects both the presence of light and the light?s position: when a laser beam hits right at the center, no current is produced, but when the beam hits off-center it causes a current to flow. The device is sensitive and fast: we tested it up to 6 kHz. Cadmium arsenide?s rapid interaction with light suggests that the future light-sensors could be made much faster still. The detector?s responsivity is comparable to that of graphene?which like cadmium arsenide is a ?Dirac semimetal??but cadmium arsenide is less susceptible to degradation.

 

Broader Impacts:

We found that cadmium arsenide can be made with a very low thermal conductivity, making it possibly useful in generating electricity from heat. We made sensors out of cadmium arsenide that detect incident optical power and have the potential to be made very fast, and we discovered that ZrSiS may be suited for making mid-infrared optical detectors that are even faster than cadmium arsenide.

            During the funded period, six undergraduates and two graduate students worked on this research. The students were trained in laser use, advanced optical techniques, cryogenics, signal processing, chemical-vapor-deposition synthesis, transport measurements, and data analysis. They participated in and contributed to every stage of the experiments, from planning to presentation of results. These students presented seven posters, delivered 14 research talks, made one oral conference presentation and authored three research papers. Four are now enrolled in Ph.D. programs.
